ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One of the best introductions to the fundamentals of Chinese. Especially with tones, which trips almost everyone up.
I learned to speak, read and write Chinese to an elementary and basic level.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Incredibly engaging classes and you learn so much! The only weakness could be time commitment. Daily classes can definitely be exhausting and hard to schedule around.

Weaknesses: I wish the grading system was organized a little better because with the way it is displayed on Canvas, it is hard to have any idea of how you're doing in the course until you receive a final grade at the end of the semester. Although I can see my grades on individual assignments/exams, it would be helpful to have access to an accurate representation of my overall score. In terms of the course itself, it is a lot of work and it is very fast-paced, but I think that is necessary to keep up with the rigor of the curriculum. I also don't feel like I learned how to write characters very well, but I think that was simply because it is hard to practice with class online. 

Strengths: Learned so much in such a short time. Since the topics are cumulative, it forces you to keep up with the work and make sure you master each lesson. Class time is so well spent; I never feel like I'm wasting my time learning things in class that could be learned in the textbook. I also found the weekly individual sessions very helpful.
It was a great course! Rigorous and engaging even despite being online.

The Chinese department is amazing at Yale. This class is challenging, you get out what you put into the class. If you were able to breeze through foreign language classes in high school, Chinese at Yale won't be like that. You have to put in the work daily. DAILY! I learned this lesson the hard way.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No class time was ever spent practicing writing characters because of the online learning environment; we were simply expected to study on our own at home. Because of this little reinforcement, I wish characters weren't tested so much on exams.
This class was a model for how to run an engaging online course. I can think of nothing that could have been improved!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! Especially if you're ethnically Chinese and can't speak like me. You'll learn a lot!

It is true that this class is a lot of work, but I'd say it's worth it. Even though this is a very basic introduction to Chinese, I learned so much about how to read, write, and speak. Students are frequently encouraged to participate, which I would normally find stressful, but the professor was always so nice and fostered a very welcoming environment. The class is very fast paced, but if you are willing to put in the effort and spend some time on the homework each day, I think it is very manageable. You get out what you put in!
Yes. You will learn more than you think you can in a semester.
